title: Certificate in Clinical Supervision | Singapore Institute of Technology

meta.description: This course is designed to equip AHP clinical supervisors and educators with the skills to provide effective clinical training to AHPs and students.

text_lines: Browse Professional Exams and Preparatory Courses
Browse Professional Exams and Preparatory Courses
This course is designed to equip AHP clinical supervisors and educators with the skills to provide effective clinical training to AHPs and students.
Demands for advanced clinical supervision competency in Allied Health Professionals (AHPs) have escalated over the past decade.

Multiple efforts such as the conversion of AHP Entry level training from a Diploma to 4 years of Bachelor study (Hon), the introduction of the Pre-Employment Clinical Training (PECT) fund, as well as the enaction of Allied Health Professions Council (AHPC) supervisory framework have increased the accountability of clinical departments to provide high-quality clinical training and assessment to AHP students and new graduates. Clinical supervisors and educators play key roles in assessing progress, facilitating learning, and supporting the well-being of learners at the workplace. It is therefore critical for clinical supervisors and educators to deliver cost-effective clinical training using evidence-based education practices.

This Certificate in Clinical Supervision is designed to equip AHP clinical supervisors and educators with the intermediate-level competencies to provide effective clinical training to AHPs and students. It aims to support clinical supervisors and educators to learn, use, and reflect on the application of evidence-based education theories and skills in clinical supervision at the workplace. The programmatic approach also seeks to develop capability and confidence amongst senior AHP educators to support the culture of teaching and learning at their workplaces through coaching junior educators.

This 4-month competency-based education programme is designed based on the “clinical teaching and supervision” and “reflective practice” competencies in the Skills map for senior AHPs under the Skills Framework for Healthcare. Learning activities will comprise e-learning, workshops, peer feedback, group coaching, and workplace application and reflection. Advanced competency will be established through multiple modes of assessment such as quizzes, short answer questions, OSTE (Objective Structured Teaching Exercise), workplace assessment, and video presentation.
The programme will be delivered by SIT faculty, together with experienced workplace clinical supervisors and educators.
Any AHP clinical supervisor or educator who is involved in supervising or educating AHPs or students on a regular basis
Senior AHPs who have the role of supporting novice junior clinical educators at their workplaces and/or who are clinical education coordinators for students’ placement
AHPs with at least three years of clinical experience, preferably with some experience in clinical education
Senior AHP clinical educators with significant experience in clinical education can apply for Recognition of Prior Learning and enroll for the
Explain the key elements of clinical teaching and supervision, clinical learning environments, and clinical evaluation models
Set clear learning expectations and goals for learners based on curriculum requirements/supervisory frameworks
Apply differentiated clinical teaching and supervision methods based on learners' learning needs
Assess and document learners' competencies and develop performance improvement plans to facilitate progression
Use evidence-based educational practice within the learning environments
Adopt effective communication techniques to improve learners' clinical learning
Evaluate personal effectiveness and develop development plans to improve clinical supervision practice
Associate Professor, Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology
Associate Professor, Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology

As one of SkillsFuture fellows, Heidi demonstrates strong commitment towards lifelong learning and developing the skills of others. With more than 20 years of experience as an Occupational Therapist (OT), Heidi holds senior clinical and education leadership roles and appointments at TTSH, in addition to her faculty role at SIT. She was instrumental in setting up the SIT clinical educator appointment system and the development of the “I am a Clinical Educator (ICE)” workshop for SIT-appointed clinical educators in 2017. Her curiosity in the science of teaching led her to complete the Master’s in Health Professions Education at Maastricht University in 2022.

Clinically, Heidi specialises in medico-legal functional capacity evaluations, Return-to-work (RTW) service development and workplace disability management. She was the principal investigator in a Ministry of Manpower (MOM)-funded study on the effectiveness of hospital-based RTW coordinators in 2012 and had collaborated closely with Workplace Safety and Health Council on the “RTW coordination in Singapore- A guide for public hospitals” to support the roll out of the national RTW programme in 2017. She is a Certified Disability Management Professional with the National Institute of Disability, Management and Research.
Associate Professor, Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology
Associate Professor, Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology

Hwee Kuan is a clinician educator with more than 20 years of physiotherapy practice. Academically, she has been a teaching faculty at SIT since 2015 and also enthusiastically engaged in post-professional physiotherapy education.

To further equip her role as a clinician educator, Hwee completed a Master of Health Professions Education at Maastricht University in 2017. Administratively, Hwee has been leading the training and staff development for Singapore General Hospital’s Physiotherapy Department since 2013. Her key responsibility is to build a training framework that complements the competency framework and the career path for SGH physiotherapists.
Hwee Kuan is also the Clinical Education Lead for SGH Allied Health Professional since 2016, where she oversees all Allied Health PECT-funded clinical attachment programmes in SGH campus.
Senior Principal Radiographer, Department of Radiology, Sengkang General Hospital
Senior Principal Radiographer, Department of Radiology, Sengkang General Hospital

Li Hoon oversees the training and development needs of Radiographers and Radiography students’ clinical placement at Sengkang General Hospital. She is an Associate Faculty for both SIT and Parkway College, and she represents the Radiography profession in AHPC as a council member.

Her keen interest in teaching and learning has led her in furthering her studies in Clinical Education as a part-time student, and she attained a Master of Science in Clinical Education from the University of Edinburgh.
Li Hoon’s keen interest in developing Allied Health Professionals has also landed her in the role of Vice Chair (Wellness, Educator & Professional Development), College of Allied Health, SingHealth.
Associate Professor/Assistant Provost (Applied Learning), Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology
Associate Professor/Assistant Provost (Applied Learning), Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology

Dr May Lim is an Associate Professor and Assistant Provost (Applied Learning) at the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT). She is the first occupational therapist in Singapore to be awarded the Doctoral of Philosophy (PhD) qualification. She started the Bachelor of Science (with Honours) in Occupational Therapy degree at SIT in 2016. May was also involved in national projects such as providing consultancy to early intervention centres. Currently, she serves at the SPD Board, volunteers as trainer at CaringSG, and partners Dementia Singapore on research initiatives. She continues her clinical practice on Friday mornings with young children with developmental delays.

May led a centre that looks after learning and teaching development at the university level from 2017 – 2022. She actively builds a coaching culture for educators to develop students beyond the classroom. She won the university Teaching Excellence Award in 2016, 2018 and 2020 and Education 2.0 Outstanding Leadership Award, National Day Honours: Public Administration Medal (Bronze) in 2022. Her research interests are transition, coaching, self-efficacy and resilience, approaches to learning, and developmental disabilities. She is a certified Solution-Focused Coach with CCPC Global, Associate Certified Coach (ACC) with International Coaching Federation (ICF) and Certified Positive Intelligence Coach.
Associate Professor / Prog Leader, Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology
Associate Professor / Prog Leader, Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology

Rahizan Zainuldin is an Associate Professor with the Health and Social Sciences (HSS) cluster and a physiotherapist by training. Together with a small group of faculty members, he co-designed the Clinical Practice Education (CPE) structure and curriculum for the undergraduate allied health programs, including clinical supervision for students. He was also the physiotherapy CPE Lead and designed competency assessments and operations for the physiotherapy CPE. He led the HSS CPE as Chair from 2020-2023.

Rahizan is a keen advocate for Entrustable Professional Activities (EPAs), a novel assessment to support entrustment decisions for learners/trainees to perform clinical tasks. He has undergone EPA assessment training internationally and is a trained designer and assessor of EPAs. He is a member of the Ministry of Health’s (MOH) Curriculum Review Standing Committee to review the development and implementation of EPAs in each undergraduate allied health CPE. He has implemented physiotherapy EPAs from 2021 and trained hundreds of clinicians in their role as clinical educators assessing physiotherapy students using EPAs at CPE. In his work on EPAs, Rahizan has published three peer-reviewed articles and presented at the OTTAWA conference, an established network for healthcare professions education and assessment.
Assistant Professor, Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology
Assistant Professor, Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology

Dr Wong Su Ren is an Assistant Professor at the Health and Social Sciences (HSS) cluster at the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) and Principal Occupational Therapist at the National University Hospital (NUH). She completed her PhD in Kinesiology, Nutrition, and Rehabilitation Science at the University of Illinois, Chicago in the area of Therapeutic Use of Self. Her current clinical specialisation is in the management of chronic conditions and mental health with close to 20 years of clinical experience.

Su Ren is an experienced educator and researcher, with a passion in mentoring and supervision. At the university, Su Ren was involved in developing and teaching modules related to complex case management and group interventions. She is a faculty supervisor for students on clinical placements and in the clinical setting, she is involved in mentoring young occupational therapists as they transition into their new professional roles. To further her interest in mentoring and coaching, Su Ren is a certified Life Coach with Life Institute, San Diego and also became a certified instructor in the Cognitive Orientation to daily Occupational Performance (CO-OPTM ) approach under the International Cognitive Approaches Network. She is also growing the research culture as the Research Director of the Department of Rehabilitation.
Senior Principal Physiotherapist, KK Women's and Children's Hospital
Senior Principal Physiotherapist, KK Women's and Children's Hospital

Caroline has two decades of clinical experience in women's and pelvic health physiotherapy. Since 2009, she has been actively involved in training and development, which has led her to take up the role of Education Lead of the Physiotherapy Department at KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital in 2017.

As a firm believer in lifelong learning, Caroline seeks to foster personal and professional growth. After obtaining a Master of Physiotherapy in Women’s Health from Melbourne University, Caroline continues to pursue a Master in Health Professions Education from Maastricht University to advance her skills in training, development, and educational leadership.

Caroline is also an associate faculty for the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT), teaching and facilitating modules on topics in physiotherapy across the lifespan, as well as professionalism and ethics. Additionally, since 2021, she has been the adjunct lecturer for the Master of Clinical Psychology at James Cook University on Interprofessional education and collaboration (IPE and IPC) with fellow IPC team to showcase the value of IPE in clinical settings.

Caroline's commitment to advancing health profession education extends to her role as a Vice Chair in the SingHealth College of Allied Health, where she provides support in the field of Rehabilitation Sciences.
Principal Occupational Therapist, National University Hospital
Principal Occupational Therapist, National University Hospital

Esther is an occupational therapist with more than 20 years of clinical experience. She has a strong interest in education and actively involves in clinical teaching for occupational therapy students. To be better equipped in education and teaching, Esther completed her Master of Science in Clinical Education at the University of Edinburgh in 2021. Having developed a special interest in interprofessional education, she is currently the chairperson of the interprofessional education committee and is actively promoting interprofessional collaboration across different departments at the National University Hospital.

Clinically, Esther specialised in paediatric, her clinical interest is social-emotional development in children and parent coaching. She completed her Master's in Health Sciences (Occupational Therapy, specialised in Paediatric) at the University of Sydney in 2007, and was certified as the DIRFloortime® Expert Training Leader under the Interdisciplinary Council in Development and Learning (ICDL) in 2016. She has been teaching DIRFloortime® certificate course locally and internationally.
Besides her clinical role as a paediatric occupational therapist, Esther is also the Clinical Education Lead for Allied Health Professional at the National University Hospital of Singapore.
Principal Physiotherapist, Tan Tock Seng Hospital
Principal Physiotherapist, Tan Tock Seng Hospital

Suhana has more than 20 years of clinical experience in neurological and neurosurgical patients at Tan Tock Seng Hospital (TTSH) and helms the Education lead portfolio at the Physiotherapy Department (TTSH) since 2016. Her key role is to oversee staff and student education including faculty development.

Suhana is an appointed Clinical Education Coordinator (CEC) with SIT since 2019. She has driven student clinical education innovations in the department since it started, exploring the different models of student education such as collaborative learning.
Apart from that, she is also a core member of the division’s education taskforce team; actively involved in developing strategic plans for allied health educators.
Under NHG College, she is the Program Director for ‘Coaching Tool for Clinical Educators’ course and the PT Lead for a simulation-based ‘Workplace Based Assessment using Mini-CEX’ workshop.
Principal Dietitian, Tan Tock Seng Hospital
Principal Dietitian, Tan Tock Seng Hospital

Teresa is an accredited practicing dietitian certified by the Dietetics Association of Australia. She obtained a Masters of Advance Dietetic Practice from University of Nottingham, United Kingdom and is currently a dietitian at Tan Tock Seng Hospital since 2008 where she provides nutritional support and dietary counselling for different patient groups, in both acute and rehabilitative settings with a clinical specialisation in oncology.

Teresa also has a keen interest in health professions education as she believes that education is a key catalyst for continuous improvement in patient care in an increasingly complex healthcare landscape. She is a member of the TTSH Allied Health (AH) education taskforce since 2011 and has been involved in department and division education initiatives involving design and implementation of workplace based assessments, needs assessments, workshops, standardised course evaluation forms, e-learning programs for collaborative learning and orientation of new AH educators with aims to upskill, provide timely support and appropriate resources for all AH educators.
She enjoys working with her fellow AH educators from various AH departments as diversity brings creativity and innovation to ensure all AH educators are well supported in their development.

Ming Li is a seasoned social work professional with over 20 years of experience in both healthcare and family service centre settings. Most recently the Principal Medical Social Worker at Tan Tock Seng Hospital, she worked with multidisciplinary teams in the delivery of psychosocial care across psychiatric medicine, palliative care, general surgery, HVRSS and family therapy services.

In her capacity as Department Supervision Lead, Ming Li was instrumental in enhancing clinical competencies and leadership skills among social workers. As a Master Supervisor, she mentored senior social workers through the clinical supervision process, ensuring high standards of client care and professional growth.

Ming Li has been an active educator and trainer, designing and facilitating a range of training programs focused on clinical supervision, healthcare response to interpersonal violence, and patient care. She has developed and delivered courses that enhance the skillsets of healthcare professionals and social workers. Her facilitation work has empowered social workers to build their clinical practice while ensuring that new and experienced supervisors alike are equipped to meet the challenges of their roles.

Ming Li holds a Degree in Social Work from National University of Singapore, Post Graduate Certificate in Clinical and Casework Supervision, and is ACTA trained. She is also a certified ASIST Trainer and Advance Care Planning Mentor and Trainer. She won the Healthcare Humanity Award in 2017, Clinical Educator (Outstanding) in 2018, 2019 and 2024, and NHG Teaching Award for Allied Health Senior Educators in 2019.
Roles and functions of a Clinical Supervisor
Concepts and frameworks in assessment (e.g., learning outcome, entrustable professional activities)
Documentation and communication of assessment progress
Determine learning outcomes for clincial training programmes
Improve utility of WBAs in clinical training
Identify causes of performance deficits and develop learning change plans
Communication with learners at different levels of progression
Focus of group coaching to be determined at workshop, based on learning needs of participants
The total hours of the course are 50 hours.
Learning theories in work-based learning (e.g., Behaviourism, Cognitivism, Constructivism and Social-culturalism)
Learning strategies (e.g. collaborative learning, interprofessional learning, reflective learning)
Application of learning theories in clinical training programmes
Approaches to facilitate collaborative learning in pairs or groups of learners, interprofessional learning across health professionals
Facilitate individual learning through critical reflection
Focus of group coaching to be determined at workshop, based on learning needs of participants
The total hours of the course are 50 hours.
Concepts and theories of psychological safety and motivation in learning
Personal development as a clinical supervisor (e.g., peer observation and feedback, personal development plan)
Creating a psychological safe learning environment
Use of strengths-based approaches in building clinical supervisory relationships
Application of coaching approaches and peer observation in clinical supervision
Focus of group coaching to be determined at workshop, based on learning needs of participants
The total hours of the course are 50 hours.
A Certificate of Attainment will be issued to participants who:
Attend at least 75% of the course
Undertake and pass non-credit bearing assessment during the course
Participants who meet the attendance requirement but do not pass the assessment will receive a Certificate of Participation.

“I found the course on clinical supervision to be incredibly valuable. It not only provided a comprehensive understanding of the principles of clinical supervision but also emphasised the importance of utilising different models for supervision, including reflective practice, assessing the progress of learning, facilitating learning, and supporting well-being.

The content was well-structured, informative, and provided practical insights that have enhanced my skills as a clinical educator. I now feel more equipped to apply diverse supervision models effectively, which has improved my ability to support the well-being of both radiographers and students. I highly recommend this course to anyone looking to enhance their supervisory abilities in a clinical setting.”
Senior Occupational Therapist, NTUC First Campus
“It has been inspiring and enriching for me. As a first-time clinical supervisor, I feel empowered and equipped, giving me more confidence as I embark on my first clinical supervisor experience.”
Principal Speech and Language Therapist, Cerebral Palsy Alliance Singapore

“By attending the course, I was able to build on my knowledge and skills in clinical supervision. The assignments allowed me to find out whether I truly understand and know how to apply what I have learned.

The lecturers were very experienced, knowledgeable, and generous with sharing their knowledge at the same time. They challenged us to reflect on our current practices and ways by which we can improve our supervision skills.”
Dietitian, Ang Mo Kio-Thye Hua Kwan Hospital
“This course has not only enabled me to gain an understanding of various teaching principles but has also enabled me to apply them into practice.”
The full fee for this course is S$7,194.00.
Funded under SkillsFuture Mid-Career Enhanced Subsidy (MCES)
All fees above include GST. GST applies to individuals and Singapore-registered companies.
